author: Masatsugu Horie
title: Toyota recalls 6.5-million cars over window switches that could ignite | Asia-Pacific
text:
Toyota. Picture: REUTERS Related articles Toyota plans to build on success of its hybrids VW loses market share in Europe amid diesel-motor recalls Farewell to a Landy beloved by so many OSAKA — Toyota is recalling about 6.5-million vehicles worldwide to fix power-window switches that can overheat and potentially lead to a fire.
About 2.7-million of the recalled vehicles are in North America, with 1.2-million in Europe and 600,000 in Japan, Toyota said on Wednesday.
The recalled models produced outside Japan include the Camry sedan and the RAV4 and Highlander sport utility vehicles.
The scale of the recall exceeds more than half a year of Toyota vehicle production. The company estimates that inspecting switches and applying heat-resistant grease will take dealers about 45 minutes per fix.
Toyota said it was unaware of any crashes caused by the fault, which resulted from inconsistent application of a sprayed-on grease to electrical contact points in the power switch.
Car makers are under pressure to hasten their recall processes after coming under fire for time lags between learning about potential flaws and calling back cars for fixes.
The pressure has built following recalls by Toyota involving unintended acceleration and General Motors for faulty ignition switches.
A litany of car makers also are repairing millions of air bags made by supplier Takata due to defective inflators.
Tokai Rika supplied the components involved in Toyota’s recall, said Kayo Doi, a spokeswoman for the car maker.
Tokai Rika will book a ¥14.5bn ($121m) charge due to a customer recall, according to a filing with the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Shares of Tokai Rika declined 1.3% to ¥2,655 in Tokyo. Toyota rose 2%, compared with a 1.8% gain in the benchmark Topix index.
Toyota received one report from a US customer of a hand being burnt, and said it was aware of 11 incidents in which switches and door trims burnt.
The internal circuit board would be replaced if the switch was not operating normally, the company said.
The recalled vehicles were produced between January 2005 and August 2006, and August 2008 and June 2010, in Japan, Toyota said.
The cars also include those manufactured outside Japan between August 2005 and August 2006, and January 2009 and December 2010, it said.
Bloomberg
